claim: All cats are mammals. Tigers belong to the cat family. Therefore, tigers are mammals

supporting.text: Cats are classified as mammals because they possess mammary glands, which are a defining characteristic of mammals.

attacks.text: Cats are classified as mammals because they possess mammary glands, which are a defining characteristic of mammals.
Not all animals in the cat family possess mammary glands, which challenges the universal classification of cats as mammals.
Scientific consensus overwhelmingly supports that all members of the cat family, including rare or extinct species, possess mammary glands.
Some genetic mutations in cats can lead to the absence of mammary glands, making them exceptions to the mammal classification.
Such mutations are extremely rare and do not change the biological classification of the entire species as mammals.

supporting.text: Tigers are part of the Felidae family, commonly known as the cat family, which is a subgroup of mammals.

attacks.text: Tigers are part of the Felidae family, commonly known as the cat family, which is a subgroup of mammals.
Some members of the Felidae family, like the extinct saber-toothed cats, may not fit all modern mammal classifications due to evolutionary differences.
Modern biological taxonomy clearly classifies all extant Felidae species as mammals, including tigers.
Common names like 'cat family' can be misleading as they don't always reflect precise biological classifications.
The term 'Felidae' is scientifically precise and universally recognized as a mammalian family in taxonomy.

supporting.text: All members of the Felidae family, including tigers, give birth to live young and nurse them with milk, which is a mammalian trait.

attacks.text: All members of the Felidae family, including tigers, give birth to live young and nurse them with milk, which is a mammalian trait.
Some members of the Felidae family might exhibit non-mammalian traits due to rare genetic mutations.
Genetic mutations causing non-mammalian traits in Felidae are extremely rare and not representative of the family as a whole.
The definition of mammals is not solely based on live birth and milk production, but also includes other traits like hair and a neocortex.
Felidae members, including tigers, possess hair and a developed neocortex, fulfilling all mammalian criteria.

supporting.text: Scientific taxonomy places both domestic cats and tigers under the class Mammalia, confirming their shared mammalian characteristics.

attacks.text: Scientific taxonomy places both domestic cats and tigers under the class Mammalia, confirming their shared mammalian characteristics.
Some species historically classified as cats, like the thylacine (Tasmanian tiger), were actually marsupials, not mammals.
The thylacine was never taxonomically classified as a felid (true cat), so it doesn't invalidate the mammalian classification of true cats.
Genetic mutations could theoretically produce a non-mammalian feline species, challenging the absolute claim.
No known genetic mutations have ever altered fundamental mammalian traits in any felid species throughout evolutionary history.

supporting.text: Tigers, like all cats, have hair or fur, which is another key feature of mammals.

attacks.text: Tigers, like all cats, have hair or fur, which is another key feature of mammals.
Not all animals with hair or fur are mammals; some extinct species had fur but were not mammals.
The presence of hair or fur is a defining characteristic of mammals, and no known exceptions exist among living species.
Some mammals, like whales, have very little hair, which challenges the necessity of fur for classification.
Whales still possess hair at some stage of development, fulfilling the mammalian requirement, even if minimal.

supporting.text: The evolutionary lineage of tigers traces back to common ancestors with other mammals, further supporting their classification as mammals.

attacks.text: The evolutionary lineage of tigers traces back to common ancestors with other mammals, further supporting their classification as mammals.
Some biologists argue that tigers share more genetic traits with reptilian ancestors than typical mammals, challenging their classification.
Genetic studies overwhelmingly confirm tigers share over 95% of their DNA with other mammals, refuting reptilian ancestry claims.
The fossil record shows transitional species between tigers and non-mammalian ancestors, complicating pure mammalian classification.
Paleontologists universally recognize transitional fossils as part of mammalian evolution, not evidence against it.
